common_name: allegheny mountain dusky salamander appalachian population
doc_citation: COSEWIC. 2018. COSEWIC assessment and status report on the Allegheny Mountain Dusky Salamander Desmognathus ochrophaeus, Appalachian population and Carolinian population in Canada. Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. Ottawa. xvi + 95 pp.
TC_assessors: Kristiina Ovaska (facilitator), Bev McBride (COSEWIC Secretariat), Anaïs Boutin, Chris Edge, Wayne Weller, David Lesbarrères, Lyne Bouthillier, Sylvain Giguère, Carine Deland, Valerie René, Christina Rohe, Joe Crowley, Daniel Vervoort, Tom Herman
TC_overall_comments: Generation time: 5-7 years; scores in red text were adjusted based on review comments from participants after the conference call
X1_iucn_comments: The agricultural land zoning of Covey Hill limits the possibilities for residential and commercial development. Cottages have been built in the past. Development on top of the hill could have an important impact on the habitat quality (water supply and quality, forest cover, sedimentation; these impacts are scored in other, appropriate categories)
X1.1_iucn_comments: Most of population is located in agricultural zoning. Severity has much uncertainty, hence a range
X1.2_iucn_comments: Intensification of commercial and industrial activities are more likely than new development
X1.3_iucn_comments: Golf courses, campgrounds, and other infrastructure developments are included. The group knew of no specific examples or proposals at present; a golf course was studied in 1990 but not approved. There is much uncertainty about timing of possible developments.
X2.1_iucn_comments: The Covey Hill area offers a great potential for maple syrup production, which can alter and reduce habitat quality but mostly through road construction or forest drainage, which are considered under other categories. Maple syrup production has been going on for a very long time so maybe no new effects would arise, but every occurrence of species is in a maple syrup production area, which may intensify. There is potential for expansion of agricultural activities on the top of the hill. This could cause forest cover removal, habitat conversion, increase of water use and reduced water quality. There are numerous orchards and vineyards and much intensification is expected in next 10 years. It is unclear how the extraction itself (other than the associated roads and human traffic, which are considered in another sections) would affect the salamanders as no forest is cleared. Therefore, the scope and severity of this threat are based mainly on the expansion of vineyards and orchards.
X2.2_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X2.3_iucn_comments: Cattle are causing habitat disturbances in some parts of the range. The impact can be locally severe where high density stocking occurs.
X2.4_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X3.1_iucn_comments: Water use and water contamination are threats associated with this type of activity. Spills related to oil and gas drilling also have the potential to contaminate groundwater and surface water; these impacts are included in 7.2 and 9.2.
X3.2_iucn_comments: The current quarrying in one municipality represents a potential threat to the species according to Deland and Sierra (2016). The possibilities for sand and rock exploitation in the second municipality are unknown. The group did not know whether significant dewatering is associated with existing mining activities in the area or whether there is expansion.
X3.3_iucn_comments: Not occurring locally in Covey Hill. However, windmill parks in the US are located just a few km from the Canadian border where the species occurs. They might expand on top of the hill, which constitutes the top of the watershed, over the short term. The impact would be through road access, deforestation, alteration of surface water or groundwater catchment. Greatest impact be due to forest removal. Also there is a potential problem of pollution through grease oil droplets to the surrounding landscape from operating windmills. Covey Hill bedrock is porous and susceptible to groundwater contamination. Impacts on salamanders in Canada are unknown but of some concern because of the proximity of the operation to the international border.
X4.1_iucn_comments: No major road construction is planned in Covey Hill, but this threat could increase with timber harvesting or agricultural development on the hill. This threat includes the unpaved roads used for forest management, maple syrup operations, recreational ATV trails, and other access roads/trails. Construction and retrofitting of bridges over streams is ongoing, and a bridge widening project is planned. The potential effects of culvert replacement are also included in this threat. The main impact would be from habitat modification, including opening of the forest canopy and creating barriers to movements (e.g., upstream to overwintering habitat). Roadkill is not an issue for this species.
X4.2_iucn_comments: This category includes transmission line corridors and communication towers. One municipality in Covey Hill has a by-law preventing the construction of new communication towers. However, it is possible to expand the existing sites. The situation is unknown for the other municipality. Maintenance (clearing of the vegetation) along the US boarder is of some concern; a 10-20 m wide opening is continuously cleared. The maintenance activities affect salamanders that reside within the corridor and also have effects on stream habitats downstream. This threat was evaluated as of a low impact by Deland and Sierra (2016). A large part of the species' range is along the international border, but most disturbance related to land clearing and infrastructure development has already occurred and was not included in the scoring.
X4.3_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X4.4_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X5.1_iucn_comments: Participants did not believe that collection of salamanders is an issue, although it may occasionally occur. Impact on population level unknown but probably minor.
X5.2_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X5.3_iucn_comments: All occurrences are from private land that is not regulated for timber harvest. The species is found in an old forest that is of high interest and of high value for exploitation. Logging is so far mostly for personal use, but sometimes all large trees have been taken. Commercial logging is a very small scale. Commercial and small-scale logging by individuals are ongoing and likely to increase in the future. Impacts are from removal of canopy and deterioration of forest floor and aquatic habitat conditions.
X6.1_iucn_comments: The use of all terrain vehicles in the habitat causes some habitat disturbances and increases the risk of habitat loss, alteration and contamination. ATVs and pickup trucks (including hunters) have been seen driving in stream bed, using the stream as an access trail. This may not be a frequent occurrences, but when it occurs, it has a large impact. Hiking and similar low-impact activities confined to trails are of minor importance. There is uncertainty about the scope, about how much recreational activity is taking place in actual salamander habitats.
X6.2_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X6.3_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill. Impacts related to roads have been discussed in a previous section.
X7.1_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill. Not a threat. Fires are uncommon to unknown.
X7.2_iucn_comments: Changes in water supply (reduction or increase) have the potential to affect the entire population. Changes in groundwater supply are of particular concern. Dams can also affect the species' habitat. Water use is potentially increasing in Covey Hill for agriculture purposes (orchards) and for bottled water operations, and the groundwater that maintain the species' habitat is also the main source of water for the citizens of Covey Hill. Any intake can affect groundwater levels and thus all salamander streams. There is uncertainty about the effect of water system changes to the salamander population, hence a range of severity scores was used.
X7.3_iucn_comments: Indirect effects on habitat were covered under other threat categories.
X8.1_iucn_comments: Chytrid fungus (Bd and Bsal) presents a potential threat to the species. However, Bd has not been reported from Desmognathus in Canada, and no mass mortalities have been reported in salamanders to this pathogen. Bsal has not been reported from North America to date.
X8.2_iucn_comments: Fish introduction occurs in Covey Hill, but contacts with the salamanders are probably limited. Ranavirus is a potential threat to this species, but no cases of ranavirus infection has been reported for the species; the host species that may act as vectors for ranavirus are found in the habitat.
X9.1_iucn_comments: Potential threat if old sceptic tanks are leaking and flow in groundwater. Not considered a threat at present.
X9.2_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X9.3_iucn_comments: This category includes sediment run-off from forestry, roads, and other land clearing or uses, and agricultural pesticides and fertilizers. Pesticides and fertilizers are commonly used in Covey Hill, and they have a strong potential to contaminate groundwater and surface waters. Conservation de la Nature Canada (2017) produced a report on pesticide use in the Covey Hill area and concluded that 64% of the pesticides used have a moderate effect on the environment, while the effects of the remaining 36% are minimal. The concentrations of contaminants in the habitat, and their impacts on the species are unknown.
X9.4_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X9.5_iucn_comments: First order streams inhabited by the species are vulnerable to the effects of acidification and contamination with heavy metals. A case study in the US found that D. fuscus was heavily impacted by acid precipitation, which led to acidification of salamander streams. There is no information on acidification or water quality in salamander streams in Covey Hill. In the US, a geological formation with low buffer capacity was at play, and this is also true at Covey Hill. It was noted that air quality in eastern US and maritime provinces in Canada has been improving over the last decade, but future trends are difficult to predict. More uncertainty about the level of contamination and impacts remain (more than for category 9.3).
X9.6_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X10.1_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X10.2_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X10.3_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Covey Hill
X11.2_iucn_comments: Hydrology models coupled with climate change scenarios suggest a high probability of drying of the seeps located at altitudes between 162 - 177 m that are used by the species over the long term (by 2050). Seasonal droughts may become more severe or more frequent on a short-term basis, potentially leading to lowering of the water table and drying up of salamander streams and seepages.
X11.4_iucn_comments: While the prediction is for longer periods of drought in summer, extreme rainfall events are predicted to become more frequent. Salamander larvae or eggs could become displaced during storm events, resulting in mortality. As an example, a recent storm event ("Irene"), resulted in the disappearance of the species from one stream after being "flushed" by the storm (C. Deland pers. comm.).

common_name: allegheny mountain dusky salamander carolinian population
doc_citation: COSEWIC. 2018. COSEWIC assessment and status report on the Allegheny Mountain Dusky Salamander Desmognathus ochrophaeus, Appalachian population and Carolinian population in Canada. Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. Ottawa. xvi + 95 pp.
TC_assessors: Kristiina Ovaska (facilitator), Bev McBride (COSEWIC Secretariat), Anaïs Boutin, Chris Edge, Wayne Weller, David Lesbarrères, Christina Rohe, Joe Crowley, Daniel Vervoort, Tom Herman
X1.1_iucn_comments: Housing developments are not a current threat in Niagara (W. Weller pers. comm.), although earlier reports indicated this to be the case. Building on table lands (on top) would have an impact on water quality and quantity (would go under other threat categories).
X1.2_iucn_comments: There is a new/expanded border crossing near the area (inspection of transport truck between US and Canada, ~5 years old), but no additional changes are expected in the next 10 years. There is unlikely to be any additional industrial or commercial development.
X1.3_iucn_comments: Niagara escarpment is a tourist and recreational area. This category deals with infrastructure development, not the recreational activities themselves. There is a zipline being built in the broader area (Whirlpool site) above the seep where Northern Dusky Salamanders are found. There has very likely been no impact on the dusky salamander population at either the Queenston site or Smeaton Creek site as a result of the 2016 construction of the climbing/zip-line recreational facility nor will there be any impact as a result of the operations of the facility (since April 2017) at Thompson Point. There is still some ongoing recreational development in the upper part. The ziplines are expected to have little impact on Allegheny Mt Salamander sites, but there is some uncertainty.
X3.3_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Niagara. Related threats are discussed under Water Use & Management.
X4.1_iucn_comments: This category includes replacement and installation of culverts and construction of new access roads, activities that are primarily applicable to one of the two salamander sites (Smeaton site). There is a culvert in place at the lower level to allow access to emergency vehicles, and repairs to the stream crossing are planned to prevent road collapse. The project will lead to the disruption of stream flow. The species is found upstream from the culvert but not at the construction site itself; however, there is potential for the disruption of the water regime and flow, impacts of which on the salamanders will be studied (Weller pers. comm.) Two culverts are currently in place along Smeaton Creek – 1 under the upper level of the emergency vehicle access road, and 1 under the lower level of this road. If there is any interruption in flow during the reconstruction of these culverts, it will occur in areas downstream of where dusky salamanders are known to occur. However, a concerted effort should be made to confirm that dusky salamanders do not occur in these stretches of Smeaton Creek.
X4.2_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Niagara. The group was not aware of anything specific.
X5.1_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Niagara. One salamander was initially taken as a voucher by researchers. Any specimens from possible new sites will be documented by photographs and tail clips.
X5.3_iucn_comments: Niagara Parks Commission manages the habitat and does not allow forest cover removal. There is no logging or wood harvesting, and the vegetation is not managed by clearing.
X6.1_iucn_comments: There is public access to the Queenston site. People could climb the bluff and walk in streams, but there is no information on the frequency of such occurrences. The salamander streams are on steep terrain, which would discourage access by most visitors. There is no public access to the Smeaton Creek site. OPG has fenced off this section of the property leased from the Niagara Parks Commission. People must obtain permission to go to the Smeaton Creek site from OPG Security, and be escorted by OPG Environment staff to the site. The public could, however, access the Smeaton Creek source location, but would have to rappel over a shear vertical face of the Niagara Gorge to get to the dusky salamander location.
X6.3_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Niagara. Threats are related to roads, discussed in Section 4.1.
X7.1_iucn_comments: Not a threat in Niagara. Fires are uncommon in the region.
X7.2_iucn_comments: Changes in hydrology, including ground water supply, have the potential to affect the entire population. Sir Adam Beck I Generating Station receives water from a canal. Some water from this canal seeps through the rocks and contributes significantly to the water flow at the Smeaton site. The flow in Smeaton is related to the water level in the canal. In the next few years (<5 years), the canal will be dried up for maintenance purposes. Smeaton Creek will then be fed only from groundwater for about one year. The situation is different in Queenston (there does not appear to be leakage from the reservoir). Severity is serious and not extreme because it mainly affects only the Smeaton site, but the entire subpopulation at that site is in jeopardy. There are also other stressors on the water table in the area, including any housing developments on the adjacent table lands that feeds the streams.
X7.3_iucn_comments: An exotic strain of Common Reed (Phragmites australis) is present along the Niagara Gorge and has been found in the species' habitat at the Queenston site. An occurrence near the source is of particular concern as it could potentially change water flow in salamander habitat; the other occurrence is near the base and could potentially grow in the stream. Seeds could be flushed downstream as well. This threat is potentially serious if it changes water flow, but there is much uncertainty about the severity over the next 10 years.
X8.1_iucn_comments: Chytrid fungus (Bd and Basal) presents a potential threat to the species. However, Bd has not been reported from Desmognathus in Canada, and no mass mortalities have been reported in salamanders to this pathogen. Basal has not been reported from North America to date.
X8.2_iucn_comments: Ranavirus is a potential threat to this species, but no cases of ranavirus infection has been reported for the species; the host species that may act as vectors for ranavirus are found in the habitat.
X9_iucn_comments: Water that drains the urbanised areas on the top of the gorge represent a potential source of groundwater and surface water contamination
X9.1_iucn_comments: Groundwater and surface water contamination is a possibility from housing developments on the surrounding table lands. There is much uncertainty about severity because the composition and concentration of potentially toxic substances in the run-off are unknown. While the effects are likely to be negative, there is much uncertainty about the severity of the impact.
X9.2_iucn_comments: A contamination event occurred in April 2016 when construction work ~700 m from the Queenston location caused the discharge of several thousand litres of unsolidified grout into the species’ habitat. Long-term impacts from contamination and physical damage to the habitat (loss of interstitial spaces in rocky substrate) are monitored but probably ongoing. Similar events are not expected to occur again, but other unexpected accidental incidents are possible; their impacts can be devastating given the small distribution of the salamanders and vulnerability of the habitat. At the Smeaton site, water enters the streams from areas where industrial and agricultural activities occur.
X9.3_iucn_comments: Groundwater and surface water contamination is a possibility from agricultural or industrial effluents. This category includes sediment runoff from agricultural and forestry operations. Water quality testing was done ~10 years ago but not in recent years. In ~2006, OPG (Ontario Power Generation) analyzed water samples taken from the source location of the Queenston site, and 4 other nearby sites (Niagara River upstream of The Falls; Welland River; OPG canal; and OPG reservoir) in an attempt to determine if the water at the Queenston Dusky Salamander locality contained industrial and/or agricultural chemicals. No water samples have ever been taken from Smeaton Creek as per the 2006 program. It will be important to do so, and possibly redo the 2006 program, because water from the OPG canal does contribute to the Smeaton Creek flow. Water in the canal is a mixture of water from both the Niagara River (potentially industrial chemicals) and the Welland River (potentially agricultural chemicals). There is much uncertainty about both scope and severity.
X9.4_iucn_comments: Garbage and solid waste are dumped along the gorge and are cumulating in the species' habitat in one locality. If chemicals (e.g.,. paint cans) were to be dumped, the habitat could be contaminated.
X9.5_iucn_comments: First order streams inhabited by the species are vulnerable to the effects of acidification and contamination with heavy metals. A case study in the US found that D. fuscus was heavily impacted by acid precipitation, which led to acidification of salamander streams. There is no information on acidification or water quality in salamander streams in Niagara. It was noted that air quality in eastern US and maritime provinces in Canada has been improving over the last decade, but future trends are difficult to predict. More uncertainty about the level of contamination and impacts remain (more than for category 9.3).
X10.3_iucn_comments: Landslides and mudslides occur along the gorge and have the potential to alter and destroy the species habitat. Landslides are a natural occurrence but could increase with more frequent storm/heavy rainfall events predicted for the future. Because of the small distribution, the population is particularly vulnerable. Scope was deemed to be large rather than pervasive because the probability of a large and serious landslide occurring at both sites within the next ten years is unlikely.
X11.2_iucn_comments: Seasonal droughts may become more severe or more frequent on a short term basis, potentially leading to lowering of the water table and drying up of salamander streams and seepages. There is no climate model specific to the local area as for the Adirondack DU, but the general trends are likely to be similar.
X11.4_iucn_comments: While the prediction is for longer periods of drought in summer, extreme rainfall events are predicted to become more frequent. Salamander larvae or eggs could become displaced during storm events, resulting in mortality.

common_name: allegheny mountain dusky salamander carolinian population
doc_citation:
Environment and Climate Change Canada. 2019. Recovery Strategy for the Allegheny
Mountain Dusky Salamander (Desmognathus ochrophaeus) – Carolinian population in
Canada. Species at Risk Act Recovery Strategy Series. Environment and Climate
Change Canada, Ottawa. 3 parts, 25 pp. + vi + 30 pp. + 5 pp.
action_subtype: Education, Monitoring, Research, Regulate human activities,  Habitat restoration,  Invasive species removal, Protection, Emergency response, Re-establishing populations, Translocation
notes_action_subtype:
1.Protect and enhance existing significant habitat for Allegheny Mountain Dusky Salamanders and Northern Dusky Salamanders in Ontario.
Identify extent of groundwater recharge area. Measure flows of seeps and streams occupied by dusky salamanders to determine seasonal and yearly averages. Have source water protection (both surface and ground water) for land in the upgradient tableland areas. Ensure that all development activities on adjacent land that may involve contaminating or lowering of the groundwater table are monitored for groundwater impacts. Control quantity and quality of stormwater discharge from adjacent land including industrial, recreational and urban areas: eliminate the application of herbicides and pesticides in the vicinity of seeps; monitor stormwater quality for pollutants; develop an emergency spills action plan for the area; create wetland areas to capture and slow down stormwater run-off; plant native trees to stabilize the slope. Monitor erosion rates on the hillsides where salamanders are found for indications of slope instability. Ensure that forest canopy remains intact. Discourage park visitors from off-trail hiking. Investigate and implement best management practices for removal of European Common Reed.
2. Conduct a thorough population study, and if necessary maintain the genetic health of Allegheny Mountain Dusky Salamander and Northern Dusky Salamander populations in Ontario.
Conduct a thorough population study to determine more accurate population size and trends for each species in Ontario: may involve mark-recapture fieldwork and/or genetic analysis. Monitor genetic health of populations: check for inbreeding with genetic analysis every 25 years. If inbreeding appears to be a concern, look into the feasibility of salamander introductions from New York State, which is the nearest population source. Search suitable/accessible habitat in Niagara Gorge for any additional populations of dusky salamanders.
3. Locate additional populations, and expand the current ranges of Allegheny Mountain Dusky Salamanders and Northern Dusky Salamanders through introductions where appropriate.
Research the probability of success if individuals are translocated from sites outside of Ontario to suitable unoccupied habitats: determine likelihood of survival; establish what numbers would be needed for a successful introduction and if they can be moved; research other potential barriers to introductions; identify areas with no obvious impediments to re-establishment; investigate potential habitat along the Niagara Escarpment and Fonthill Kame Morraine.  If potential habitat is found (and successful introduction seems likely), pilot an introduction project.

4. Elicit public support and collaboration in the protection and recovery of Allegheny Mountain Dusky Salamanders and Northern Dusky Salamanders in Ontario.
Prepare educational materials such as pamphlets to inform park visitors about the endangered status of these salamanders and the need to not disturb them or their habitat.
action_type: Outreach and stewardship, Research and monitoring, Habitat management, Population management

doc_citation: Environment and Climate Change Canada. 2019. Recovery Strategy for the American Chestnut (Castanea dentata) in Canada. Species at Risk Act Recovery Strategy Series. Environment and Climate Change Canada, Ottawa. 3 parts, 37 pp. + vi + 43 pp. + 5 pp.
action_subtype: Education, Monitoring, Research, Protection, Treat disease, Captive breeding, Re-establishing populations
notes_action_subtype:
Survey and monitor status of known and newly discovered populations within the species’ native range. Monitor and maintain planted populations located within the species’ native range in Ontario as potential sources of blight-free native germplasm. Promote protection of known populations of American Chestnut to land management authorities, private landowners and recovery teams, Promote public awareness of American Chestnut.
Investigate the effectiveness of various chestnut blight control measures in an experimental setting, Identify, manage and monitor at least 15 American Chestnut populations of those inventoried within the species’ native range. Develop techniques to decrease species’ vulnerability to chestnut blight, test effects of spreading hypovirulent strains of chestnut blight, conduct an intraspecific and interspecific breeding program for blight resistance in American Chestnut, Restrict inter-jurisdictional movement of all Castanea species in Canada.
Locate and inventory blight-free American Chestnut stands planted in Ontario outside the species’ native range, Monitor and protect at least two blight-free stands planted outside the species’ native range in Ontario
action_type: Outreach and stewardship, Research and monitoring, Habitat management, Population management

doc_citation: Environment and Climate Change Canada. 2019. Recovery Strategy for the American Columbo (Frasera caroliniensis) in Canada. Species at Risk Act Recovery Strategy Series. Environment and Climate Change Canada, Ottawa. 3 parts, 27 pp. + vi + 23 pp. + 5 pp.
action_subtype: Education, Monitoring, Research, Habitat restoration, Protection,  Invasive species removal, Re-establishing populations, Seed storage
notes_action_subtype: Main objectives: 1. Protect and manage extant populations and their habitats. 2. Identify and, where necessary, manage threats to populations and habitats. 3. Determine population trends and changes to habitat conditions through regular monitoring. 4. Where feasible and necessary, facilitate recruitment, augment existing populations and consider re-establishing populations at historical sites in suitable habitat. 5. Address knowledge gaps related to population status, management, life history, and severity of threats.
action_type: Outreach and stewardship, Research and monitoring, Habitat management, Population management
X2_notes: The primary threats to American Columbo in southwestern Ontario include habitat loss and fragmentation due to urban and agricultural development

doc_citation: Environment and Climate Change Canada. 2018. Recovery Strategy for the American Ginseng (Panax quinquefolius) in Canada. Species at Risk Act Recovery Strategy Series. Environment and Climate Change Canada, Ottawa. vii + 32 pp.
action_subtype: Education, Monitoring, Research, Protection, Regulate human activities, Habitat restoration, Re-establishing populations, Manage native species negatively impacting species at risk, Invasive species removal
notes_action_subtype:
Provide legal protection or binding stewardship status to areas of significance for the species implement beneficial management practices (BMP) at the local and landscape levels in order to mitigate threats, with an emphasis on illegal harvest as well as plant and seed mortality, restore habitats and reintroduce the species within historical and extirpated occurrences, Conduct demographic and genetic studies to clarify how American Ginseng populations respond to various threats, study aspects related to the propagation of individuals (e.g., pollinators; ex situ cultivation for transplantation and reintroduction purposes; short and long distance dispersal pathways)
 Establish partnerships with governmental departments and agencies, conservation organizations, Indigenous communities, private landowners and the commercial cultivation industry in order to implement a training/outreach/restoration/reintroduction program, improve the communication and data management for species with sensitive data, promote and verify the compliance with existing environmental laws, regulations and policies to prevent breaches and offenses for all types of activities on all types of land tenures, develop new policies and programs where gaps exist habitats and reintroduce the species within historical and extirpated occurrences
action_type: Outreach and stewardship, Research and monitoring, Habitat management, Population management
X2_notes: not specific: urban and agricultural activities have resulted in high levels of habitat loss and continue to put pressure on the mature forests that remain in the landscape

doc_citation: Environment and Climate Change Canada. 2018. Management Plan for the Ancient Murrelet (Synthliboramphus antiquus) in Canada. Species at Risk Act Management Plan Series. Environment and Climate Change Canada, Ottawa. iv + 33 pp.
action_subtype: Education, Monitoring, Research, Regulate human activities, Invasive species removal, protection
notes_action_subtype:
1.        Develop restoration plans for key colonies: Develop restoration plans for the four suggested administrative areas 
2.        Develop and support programs aimed at reducing threats: Prioritize and implement predator eradication projects at Ancient Murrelet colonies throughout the Canadian breeding range. Ensure that zoning and public land use restrictions currently in place for Ancient Murrelet colonies are actively monitored and enforced. Collaborate with the National Aerial Surveillance Program (NASP) and the Integrated Satellite Tracking of Polluters (ISTOP) to ensure that oiling deterrence measures and oil hotspot mapping are implemented in areas important to Ancient Murrelet, including Haida Gwaii. Collaborate with appropriate jurisdictions to support and improve existing bycatch reduction measures. This may include: placing at-sea observers on boats, exploring opportunities to introduce electronic monitoring systems, and encouraging the investigation of innovative bycatch reduction techniques.
3.        Undertake research and monitoring : Establish baseline monitoring protocols to assess population size and status at each colony location, Investigate and implement cost-effective introduced predator monitoring techniques to track predator activity and ensure that predators are not re-introduced in restored colonies. Conduct further research on attraction and retention of prospecting adults at vacant breeding colonies using social cues. Expand collaboration, research, and monitoring to address information knowledge gaps regarding location and movement of Ancient Murrelets during the non-breeding season. Conduct further research to assess and monitor the effects of oceanographic changes on colonies other than those currently covered by the Laskeek Bay Conservation Society.
4.        Increase public awareness
notes_CC_action_subtype: Conduct further research to assess and monitor the effects of oceanographic changes on colonies other than those currently covered by the Laskeek Bay Conservation Society.
action_type: Outreach and stewardship, Research and monitoring, Habitat management

doc_citation: COSEWIC. 2018. COSEWIC assessment and status report on the Athabasca Endemics, Large-headed Woolly Yarrow (Achillea millefolium var. megacephala), Athabasca Thrift (Armeria maritima ssp. interior), Mackenzie Hairgrass (Deschampsia mackenzieana), Sand-dune Short-capsuled Willow (Salix brachycarpa var. psammophila), Turnor’s Willow (Salix turnorii), Blanket-leaved Willow (Salix silicicola), and Floccose Tansy (Tanacetum huronense var. floccosum) in Canada. Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. Ottawa. xlvii + 83 pp.
report_writers: Lamb E , Hilger H, Attanayake A U
TC_assessors: Jen Heron (facilitator), D. Meidinger (co-chair), J. James (Secretariat), Candace Neufeld (ECCC), Mieke Hagesteijn (ECCC), Phil McLaughlin (U Sask), Eric Lamb (SSC, U Sask, writer), Joyce Gould (VP SSC, AB Parks), Ruben Boles (ECCC), Jim Pojar (VP SSC), Dan Brunton (VP SSC), Hannah Hilger (U Sask, writer), and Udayanga Attanayaken (U Sask, writer)
TC_overall_comments: Decided to use 3 generation time of 15-20 years for assessing severity. Overall threats: remote area, main threats not serious but interacting together over longer term, no planned development. Agreement low overall.
X3.2_iucn_comments: Mineral exploration has recently occurred in the Athabasca region, however there are no currently operating or permitted mines near to the Athabasca Sand Dunes.
X4.1_iucn_comments: A winter route exists along the west boundary of Athabasca Sand Dunes provincial park; proposals to build an all-weather road in the region have been made but are currently inactive.
X5.2_iucn_comments: Occasional collection of voucher specimens or seeds likely occurring. Unlikely to have any significant effect on the populations.
X6.1_iucn_comments: Ecotourism primarily canoe trippers who stop to walk into the dunes occasionally occurs. Most areas of the dune fields are inaccessible on foot so the impacts will be very small and restricted to areas near the Lake Athabasca shoreline and McFarlane River. Occasional ATV use noted (old tracks seen in 2009-10 surveys). ATVs have the potential to severely damage gravel pavements. Currently the threat is very low due to the inaccessibility of the site; development of roads that provide improved access would greatly increase the severity of this threat. Walking and ATV most severe on gravel pavement but these sites occur quite a distance from shoreline so mostly inaccessible at this time. Most species unlikely to be impacted by foot traffic; but Athabasca Thrift different -- acutely sensitive to burial; stones stabilize the sand. Anything that disrupts pavement, can change sand accumulation. Snow machines discussed. Snow protecting surface in flats with Athabasca Thrift Boat or canoe accessible areas > 1% except for Athabasca Thrift.
X6.3_iucn_comments: Some subsistence hunting (First Nations -- not recreation) is taking place but likely of low impact to plants. Will sometimes take boat across lake to go hunting but doesn't happen very often. Hunting done on foot, hauling caribou manually, so not travelling far.
X7.1_iucn_comments: Forests establishing on less active dunes leading to dune stabilization and decreases in Dune area. Not linked to current fire suppression (little active fire suppression in Athabasca region), but expansion of industry and infrastructure in the region could lead to an expansion of fire suppression. Fire itself is a net positive factor. Reduction in fire frequency, if it occurs due to future fire suppression, could have an impact - so timing considered only possible in long term. Scope small as it was determined by forest edge that might allow for encroachment.
X8.1_iucn_comments: Currently no invasive species noted in dunes, but reports of potentially invasive species in surrounding area. Populations of Smooth Brome and Clover present on North shore of lake Athabasca and in settlements in region. These invasives likely to spread rapidly if accidentally introduced to dune region, accelerating dune stabilization. Potential invasives well adapted to spread in dune but more likely an issue in the moister areas -- not where Athabasca Thrift occurs.
X8.2_iucn_comments: Forests establishing on less active dunes leading to dune stabilization and decreases in Dune area. Not linked to fire suppression (little active fire suppression in Athabasca region), potentially linked to larger scale climate driven changes in fire regime but treated here as mechanism is uncertain. Eric Lamb has a paper in preparation on changes in dune area due to difference in area of encroachment in west and new dune formation in east. Higher rate of forest on west vs spread on east --> smaller total dune area. Proximate driver is movement of forest onto active sand; ultimate driver could be fire or climate related. Fires typically left to burn so changes in fire regime linked to climate. Over 10 years, scope is less than 10% Severity determined by surveys in wooded habitat in margins of dune fields and comparing the relative subpopulation sizes between open dune and a forested area on dune margin--greater impact for Athabasca Thrift than other taxa. Although encroachment/recruitment of dune habitat might be considered part of natural dune succession, there is a change going on and the mechanism is unknown.
X9.5_iucn_comments: Acid deposition throughout Athabasca region documented. Current evidence indicates potential severity is low, but deposition is ongoing and may have cumulative impacts. Acid deposition is an issue of nitrogen oxide deposition from oil sands. A number of assessments as to what deposition rates are. Research Eric Lamb did a few years ago where they grew individuals in sand from dune area and looked at mortality rates and growth impacts. Conclusion of limited effects at current rates of deposition. Longer term uncertainty. Not a cumulative effect. Minor impact on root growth rates. Unlikely major mortality.
X11.1_iucn_comments: Changes in wind patterns addressed here -- changes in recruitment/encroachment might be related to climate change, but dealt with in 8.2. Changing prevailing wind direction will affect sand sources and potentially dune movement and stabilization patterns. Climate data from uranium mine from 1970 to 2014; observed change in wind patterns. Dunes only move when you have upwind sand source and primary sand source is beaches on Athabasca Lake to the north of dune fields. Wind should be high in June & July to influence dune movement when it's dry. OK in May June but high wind changes to the other direction around July August. Do not have long-term data. Severity unknown during timeframe of potential impact.
X11.2_iucn_comments: Rick Schneider report of climate change in AB -- NE corner of AB subject to considerable drying out; Lake Athabasca would be impacted. Drought may not have a big impact though as dunes are overall droughty and dry periods are when dunes are active. Impact potentially greatest on water table and its affect on moisture conditions in dune slack areas. But, species are extremely good at getting at ground water. Proportion of dune slack area used for Scope; could be species differences but severity unknown at this time.
X11.3_iucn_comments: No data to say whether extreme temperatures would be an issue; taxa well adapted to extreme cold and likely heat. Decision not to score this threat.
X11.4_iucn_comments: Wind storms a threat? General agreement no.

doc_citation: Environment and Climate Change Canada. 2019. Management Plan for the Band-tailed Pigeon (Patagioenas fasciata) in Canada. Species at Risk Act Management Plan Series. Environment and Climate Change Canada, Ottawa. iii + 14 pp.
action_subtype: Education, Research, Monitoring, Protection, Regulate human activities,
notes_action_subtype: Monitoring mineral sites is currently believed to be the most effective means of assessing Band-tailed Pigeon trends at the population level. The Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) started identifying mineral sites in British Columbia in 2001 and will continue to do so on an ongoing basis. The Canadian Wildlife Service’s National Harvest Survey (NHS) (which consists of the Harvest Questionnaire Survey and the Species Composition Survey) annually assesses the number of active hunters and the Band-tailed Pigeon harvest. The NHS will continue to be conducted annually to ensure that hunting is kept at a sustainable level. CWS and the B.C. Ministry of Forests, Lands, and Natural Resources Operations work together to ensure that hunting limits are set to reflect population status and threats. The Canadian Wildlife Service will continue to monitor band returns of birds hunted to determine population trends, demography, and population connectivity. In order to achieve the management objective, conservation measures will be organized under the following three broad strategies:  Population monitoring and surveys, Habitat conservation and stewardship, Research"
action_type: Outreach and stewardship, Research and monitoring, Habitat management

Stewardship and conservation and Research and inventory : A survey of Batwing Vinyl Lichen populations in B.C. was conducted in 2009 as part of the compilation of the COSEWIC (2011) Assessment and Status Report on this species; three populations known from 1968 and 1975 were searched for, but not found, and are considered to be extirpated. A fourth historical population was found to still exist. Two additional populations were discovered in 2009, ten new populations in 2012/2013 and one new population in 2017. There are likely more populations and more surveys are needed to locate them.
